comments.body: Can we document feature gate requirements here too?

This object kind is available regardless of the feature gate. This is the key difference to other, earlier alpha and beta object kinds which were only registered when their flag was set.

What we can say here is "They are consumed by the kube-scheduler if the CSIStorageCapacity beta feature gate is enabled and a CSI driver opts into capacity-aware scheduling with CSIDriver.StorageCapacity.".

Is that okay?
As discussed on chat, I added that sentence.
Side note: I noticed the other objects in here, StorageClass, VolumeAttachment are not deprecated. Should we go ahead and deprecate them (in a separate PR)?

Originally, the plan was to deprecate whole group-versions, but that seems to have shifted in machinery.

@liggitt or @lavalamp - thoughts?  Should we deprecate individual types from a group?  I don't think we can, really.
I'll go ahead and deprecate the other objects in a separate pr

I'm not sure I buy this.  At all.  Deprecation policy says:

Rule #1: API elements may only be removed by incrementing the version of the API group.

Because this is new, you also have to define the behavior of absence.  So for example,

"If this annotation is not present, the CSI implementation must assume the cluster does not support ephemeral inline volume sources, and that this volume is therefore persistent."
Doesn't have to be inline to the annotation, you could move it to a separate paragraph after the annotations are listed.

Added this paragraph:

"csi.storage.k8s.io/ephemeral" is a new feature in Kubernetes 1.16. It is only
required for drivers which support both modes. Other drivers can leave pod info
disabled and/or ignore this field. As Kubernetes 1.15 doesn't support this field,
drivers can only support one mode when deployed on such a cluster and the
deployment determines which mode that is, for example via a command line parameter
of the driver.
missing `+optional` comment.
Fixed
Make sure to sync the comments from all the types.go files
Fixed
Why is this list per-driver-per-node?  Wouldn't all nodes have the exact same values?
Different drivers may need different topology keys.  This is to keep track of which keys each driver uses so we know which topology values to pass to the driver.

Oh sorry I misinterpreted the question.  The CSI spec reports topology keys per node, so it does allow for nodes to use different topology keys. I don't see an immediate use case for this, but we have adapted our design so that it can work.
blech, OK
Maybe a note about who creates/manages this resource
Sure
Can you repeat the validation rules here, so I don't have to go digging to understand it?
Sure.  The driver name must be 63 characters or less, beginning and ending with an alphanumeric character ([a-z0-9A-Z]) with dashes (-), dots (.), and alphanumerics between.

Something to consider for the future: If I want to build a generic monitoring system that can verify that all the nodes that a CSI driver needs to be on has a CSI driver that is healthy, it would be useful to include a NodeSelector field in here that explicitly identifies the subset of nodes the CSI driver is being installed on. Absence of such a selector could mean the entire cluster.
Ok
Is this requirement validated somewhere?
Edit: nm
Wait sorry this is not right. I was talking about the NodeId field
ValidateNodeName will be used to validate the node name.  Also kubelet will make sure this is a K8S node when installing CSINodeInfo.
Is this really a required field?
no, if the driver doesn't support topology, then this can be empty

The regex for CSI Driver name does not match this description:

`^[a-zA-Z0-9][-a-zA-Z0-9_.]{0,61}[a-zA-Z-0-9]$` - that requires at least 2 characters. Is that the intention of the CSI spec?  @saad-ali
The CSI spec references [rfc1035](https://tools.ietf.org/html/rfc1035#section-2.3.1) for valid syntax. Can we use `IsDNS1035Label` to validate the csi name instead?
I can do that, but it will give us different results from apivalidation.ValidateCSIDriverName as "_" won't be supported.  I can add a different validation.

The csi spec does not allow "_", so it appears that `ValidateCSIDriverName` is wrong. Can we fix the original validation method? It would technically be a breaking change since we would be tightening validation :-/
Will we be breaking any drivers by doing this?  I wonder if we need to add warning messages first and then remove support for _?
Yes.

- DNS1035 starts with a letter while the CSI spec says CSI driver name starts with an alphanumeric character.
- DNS1035 does not allow _ and CSI spec also does not include _ in CSI driver name. So this one is just added in our own validation somehow.
- Also the DNS1035 label itself does not include a ".".  "." is used between a subdomain and a label.  CSI spec allows "." in the middle of the driver name.

We should not have "silent defaults".  You should document that the default value is true, and then add logic in the defaulting code that detects nil and assigns the value.  This captures the API-version-specific default value, and means that code which consumes this type does not need to know what to do in case of nil.  Concretely, imagine that the default value changed between API version 1 and API version 2.  If backend code finds nil, how does it know what the user intended?

I'll look for and flag this if I see it elsewhere, but please scrub for this anti-pattern and fix all such cases.

Sorry I thought I had already made a comment about this but I must have been dreaming.  Here's an example of how we [default other storage fields](https://sourcegraph.com/github.com/kubernetes/kubernetes/-/blob/pkg/apis/storage/v1/defaults.go)
Will do.
